fd_vs_ppf_calculator.meta_title: FD vs PPF Calculator 2025 ‚Äî Compare Returns, Tax & Maturity (Free Tool)
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.meta_description: Use our free FD vs PPF calculator to compare maturity amounts, tax impact and post-tax returns. Includes premium charts, examples, and downloadable CSV. Updated Sep 2025.
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.og_description: Compare Fixed Deposit vs PPF returns instantly ‚Äî see pre/post-tax maturity, graphs, and downloadable plan. Free FD vs PPF calculator (India).
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.h1: FD vs PPF Returns Calculator 2025 ‚Äî Compare Fixed Deposit & PPF
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.description: Enter your investment amount and tenure to see a side-by-side comparison of maturity value, tax impact, and post-tax returns for Fixed Deposits and Public Provident Fund. Make an informed decision.
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.title: FD vs PPF Calculator
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.form_description: Compare post-tax returns from a lump-sum FD vs recurring PPF investment.
fd_vs_ppf_calculator.result_snapshot: For this scenario, {winner} wins by approximately {difference} after tax.

clarifier_note.title: Important ‚Äî How We Compare
clarifier_note.body: The calculator treats the 'Investment Amount' as a one-time lump-sum for the FD and as a recurring annual deposit for PPF. This means the total money deployed differs. For example, a ‚Çπ1 lakh investment becomes a ‚Çπ1 lakh single deposit in FD vs. a total of ‚Çπ15 lakh (1L √ó 15 years) in PPF. This models a common real-world investment choice.

assumptions.title: Calculator Assumptions
assumptions.body:
• PPF is modelled with annual compounding at the specified rate and a default maturity of 15 years. Deposits are assumed at the start of each year.
  • FD is modelled as a one-time lump-sum with annual compounding. Interest is taxed at your selected marginal rate.
  • Results are nominal (not inflation-adjusted). Always verify with official sources like PFRDA and the Income Tax Dept.

quick_answer.title: Quick Answer: Which is better, FD or PPF?
quick_answer.body: For long-term, tax-free wealth creation (like retirement), PPF is almost always better due to its EEE tax status and compounding benefits. For short-term goals or emergency funds where you need liquidity, an FD is more suitable despite the tax on interest. Use our PPF Calculator or NPS Calculator to see the exact difference for your amount.

example1.title: Example 1 ‚Äî FD (Lump-Sum)
example1.body:
Input: ‚Çπ100,000 lump-sum, 7% p.a., 15 years.
Calculation:
  1. Future Value = 100,000 √ó (1.07)^15 = ‚Çπ275,903.
  2. Total Interest = 275,903 - 100,000 = ‚Çπ175,903.
  3. Tax on Interest (30%) = 0.30 √ó 175,903 = ‚Çπ52,771.
  4. Post-Tax Maturity = 275,903 - 52,771 = ‚Çπ223,132.

example2.title: Example 2 ‚Äî PPF (Recurring Annual Deposit)
example2.body:
Input: ‚Çπ100,000 paid at the start of each year for 15 years, 7.1% p.a.
Calculation (Annuity Due Formula):
Future Value = P √ó [((1 + r)^n - 1) / r] √ó (1 + r)
This computes to a tax-free maturity of ‚Çπ2,712,139 on a total investment of ‚Çπ1,500,000.

ppf_features.title: PPF: Key Features, Rules & Tax Benefits
points: Tax Treatment: Exempt-Exempt-Exempt (EEE). Contributions, interest, and maturity are all tax-free. (Source: Income Tax Dept)
Lock-in Period: 15 years, can be extended in blocks of 5 years.
Interest Rate: Set by the government quarterly. Generally higher than FD rates. (Source: NSI)
Contribution Limit: Min ‚Çπ500, Max ‚Çπ1.5 lakh per financial year.
Best For: Long-term goals like retirement, children's education, and disciplined, tax-free saving.

fd_features.title: FD: Key Features, Rules & Tax Implications
points: Tax Treatment: Interest earned is fully taxable as per your income tax slab.
Lock-in Period: Flexible, ranging from 7 days to 10 years. Premature withdrawal is possible with a penalty.
Interest Rate: Fixed at the time of investment for the entire tenure. Varies by bank and tenure.
Contribution Limit: No upper limit on investment.
Insurance: Deposits are insured up to ‚Çπ5 lakh by DICGC. (Source: DICGC)
Best For: Short to medium-term goals, emergency funds, and predictable returns for risk-averse investors.

comparison.title: FD vs PPF: Detailed Comparison Table

tax_impact.title: Tax Impact Explained (how tax affects effective returns)
tax_impact.body: The biggest difference between FD and PPF is tax. Interest from an FD is added to your 'Income from Other Sources' and taxed at your marginal slab rate. For example, if you are in the 30% tax bracket, a 7% FD effectively yields only 4.9% post-tax. In contrast, the entire interest earned from PPF is tax-free, making its effective return much higher.

checklist.title: How to Choose: A Quick Checklist
points: Goal Horizon: Long-term (>10 years)? PPF is better. Short-term (<5 years)? FD is the only option.
Tax Bracket: In a higher tax bracket (20-30%)? The tax-free nature of PPF becomes much more attractive.
Liquidity Needs: Need access to your money for emergencies? FD offers better liquidity, despite penalties.
Risk Appetite: If you want zero risk, both are safe, but PPF is backed by the sovereign government.
Investment Amount: Investing over ‚Çπ1.5 lakh annually? You'll have to use FDs or other options for the surplus.
Age: For senior citizens, banks often offer higher FD rates, which might make them more competitive.

faqs.question: FD vs PPF ‚Äî which is better?
faqs.answer: It depends: PPF is better for long-term, tax-free growth; FD is better for short-term goals and liquidity. Use the calculator to compare the exact numeric outcome for your inputs.

faqs.question: How to calculate FD returns after tax?
faqs.answer: Compute FD future value with compound interest, subtract the original principal to get interest earned, then apply your marginal tax rate to that interest to find tax owed. Post-tax maturity = gross maturity ‚àí tax.

faqs.question: How is PPF interest calculated?
faqs.answer: PPF interest is compounded annually at the rate notified quarterly by the government. If you deposit at the start of each year (annuity-due), the formula uses an annuity multiplier.

faqs.question: What if I want to compare equal total investments?
faqs.answer: This feature is coming soon. Currently, the tool compares a one-time FD investment against a recurring PPF investment, which is a common real-world scenario.

faqs.question: Does PPF allow early withdrawals?
faqs.answer: Partial withdrawals are permitted from the 7th financial year under limits; loans are available between years 3 and 6. Full premature closure is allowed only in specific cases (e.g., serious illness) and may carry a penalty.

faqs.question: Is FD interest taxable?
faqs.answer: Yes ‚Äî FD interest is taxable at your marginal income tax slab. TDS (10%) is applicable above statutory thresholds; however, actual tax liability will depend on your slab.

faqs.question: Can I claim tax benefits for FD?
faqs.answer: Only 5-year tax-saving FDs qualify for deduction under Section 80C; their interest remains taxable.

faqs.question: Should a senior citizen choose FD or PPF?
faqs.answer: Many seniors use a mix ‚Äî FDs for monthly income (banks give senior citizen rates) and PPF if they want a tax-free long-term corpus. The calculator helps quantify trade-offs.

faqs.question: What happens if I miss a PPF deposit?
faqs.answer: Missing the minimum contribution makes the account inactive; revival requires payment for missed years plus a penalty per missed year. Check your bank/Post Office for exact revival process.

faqs.question: Are PPF rates fixed forever?
faqs.answer: No ‚Äî PPF rates are reviewed and notified by the government quarterly. The calculator allows you to edit the rate to model different scenarios.

faqs.question: Can NRIs open PPF accounts?
faqs.answer: NRIs cannot open new PPF accounts; existing accounts continue under specific conditions. Confirm current rules with the bank/Post Office and official guidelines.

faqs.question: How can I use FD laddering with PPF?
faqs.answer: A common strategy: max out PPF for tax-free long-term growth, and ladder FDs with staggered maturities for liquidity. This balances safety, liquidity and tax efficiency.

conclusion.title: Final Thoughts: Making the Right Choice
conclusion.body: Choosing between a Fixed Deposit and the Public Provident Fund ultimately depends on your financial goals, investment horizon, and need for liquidity. For secure, tax-free, long-term growth, PPF is an unmatched tool. For predictable returns on short-term savings, an FD provides reliability and access. Use our FD vs PPF Returns Calculator to model various scenarios and make an informed decision that best suits your financial plan.

retirement_corpus_calculator.meta_title: Retirement Corpus Calculator 2025 ‚Äî How Much to Save to Retire in India (SIP & Lump Sum)
retirement_corpus_calculator.meta_description: Use our free Retirement Corpus Calculator (India) ‚Äî includes inflation, pre/post-retirement returns, life expectancy, existing savings and worked examples (‚Çπ6L/‚Çπ10L/‚Çπ15L). Export results & get a 1-page retirement plan.
retirement_corpus_calculator.h1: Retirement Corpus Calculator ‚Äî How Much Money Do You Need to Retire in India (2025)
retirement_corpus_calculator.intro: A retirement corpus is the total sum of money you need to support yourself after you stop working. Our calculator helps you move beyond a simple number to create a complete plan for a secure retirement.
retirement_corpus_calculator.title: Retirement Corpus Calculator
retirement_corpus_calculator.form_description: Plan your comfortable retirement by calculating the total corpus you need.

assumptions.title: Assumptions We Use (Default)
assumptions.body:
• Inflation: 6% p.a.
  • Pre-retirement returns: 12% p.a.
  • Post-retirement returns: 7% p.a.
  • Deposits: monthly, made at the start of each month (annuity-due).
  • Life expectancy: 85 years (adjustable).
  • Figures are nominal (not inflation-adjusted). This calculator is an estimator; consult a CFP for a personalised plan.

how_it_works.title: How Our Retirement Corpus Calculator Works
how_it_works.body:
We use standard financial formulas to give you an accurate projection. Here‚Äôs a simplified look at how we do it:

  • Future Value of Your Expenses: We first calculate how much your current monthly expenses will grow to by the time you retire, using the inflation rate you provide. The formula is: Future Expense = Present Expense √ó (1 + Inflation Rate) ^ Years to Retirement.
  • Total Corpus You Need: Next, we calculate the total lump sum you'll need on the day you retire. This is the amount that, when invested, will generate enough income to cover your expenses for the rest of your life.
  • Your Required Monthly SIP: Finally, we determine the monthly Systematic Investment Plan (SIP) needed to bridge the gap between your current savings and your target corpus. We calculate the future value of your existing savings and subtract it from the required corpus to find the shortfall.

inputs_explained.title: What Your Inputs Mean and Why They Matter
inputs_explained.body:
To get an accurate result, you need to provide some key details. Here‚Äôs what each one means for your plan:

  • Your Current & Retirement Age: This defines your investment horizon. The longer you have, the more the power of compounding can work for you, meaning you can start with smaller investments.
  • Your Current Monthly Expenses: This is the foundation of your retirement plan. Be realistic about what you spend today to get an accurate picture of what you'll need tomorrow.
  • Your Current Savings: This is your head start! Any money you've already saved in EPF, PPF, Mutual Funds, or other investments reduces the amount you'll need to save in the future.
  • Inflation Rate (we default to 6%): This is the silent wealth killer. Inflation reduces the purchasing power of your money over time. A higher inflation rate means you'll need a much larger corpus.
  • Pre-Retirement Returns (we default to 12%): This is the growth rate you expect on your investments while you're still working. A higher return means your money works harder for you, and you can reach your goal with smaller SIPs.
  • Post-Retirement Returns (we default to 7%): This is the return you expect on your corpus after you retire. We assume a more conservative, capital-preserving portfolio here.

worked_examples.title: Worked Examples ‚Äî How Much Corpus Do You Need?

scenario1.title: Example 1: Middle-Income Salaried (‚Çπ10 LPA)
scenario1.body:
Your Situation: You're 30, planning to retire at 60. Your monthly expenses are ‚Çπ50,000, and you've already saved ‚Çπ5 lakh.
Our Calculation: To maintain your lifestyle, you'll need a retirement corpus of approximately ‚Çπ3.28 Crore. To reach this goal, you should start a monthly SIP of ‚Çπ18,250.

scenario2.title: Example 2: High-Income, Later Start (‚Çπ25 LPA)
scenario2.body:
Your Situation: You're 35, aiming to retire at 60. Your monthly expenses are ‚Çπ1 lakh, and your current savings are ‚Çπ20 lakh.
Our Calculation: You'll need a corpus of around ‚Çπ4.79 Crore. To achieve this, you should start a monthly SIP of ‚Çπ37,842.

scenario3.title: Example 3: Freelancer, Early Start (‚Çπ7 LPA)
scenario3.body:
Your Situation: You're a 25-year-old freelancer with monthly expenses of ‚Çπ30,000 and savings of ‚Çπ2 lakh.
Our Calculation: Your target corpus is ‚Çπ3.04 Crore. Thanks to your long investment horizon, you only need to start a monthly SIP of ‚Çπ7,725 to get there.

accumulation_strategy.title: How to Reach Your Retirement Corpus ‚Äî Strategies & Vehicles
accumulation_strategy.body:
Choosing Your Investment Path: SIP vs. Lump Sum

  • Systematic Investment Plan (SIP): This is the most disciplined approach. You invest a fixed amount regularly (e.g., monthly), which helps you average out market highs and lows (rupee-cost averaging) and benefit from compounding. It's perfect for building wealth steadily over time.
  • Step-up SIP: This is a supercharged version of a regular SIP. You increase your monthly investment amount annually, usually in line with your salary hike (e.g., by 10%). This simple step can dramatically accelerate your journey to your target corpus.

Your Asset Mix: How It Should Change with Age

Your investment strategy shouldn't be static. As you get closer to retirement, you should gradually shift from high-risk, high-return assets to safer options to protect your capital.

  • In Your 20s & 30s: Be aggressive. A portfolio with 70-80% in equities (like mutual funds) can generate higher returns over the long term.
  • In Your 40s: Start balancing your risk. A 60:40 split between equity and debt is a common strategy.
  • In Your 50s and Beyond: It's time to preserve your capital. Shift your portfolio to be debt-heavy (70-80% in fixed-income instruments).

How PPF, NPS, & EPF Fit Into Your Plan

These are the foundational pillars of retirement planning in India. Your current savings in these instruments give you a massive head start.

  • EPF (Employee Provident Fund): A mandatory saving for salaried individuals, forming a solid, risk-free base for your retirement fund.
  • PPF (Public Provident Fund): A tax-free, government-backed scheme perfect for long-term, risk-averse savings.
  • NPS (National Pension System): A market-linked product that offers a mix of equity and debt, providing tax benefits and the potential for higher returns.

deaccumulation_strategy.title: The De-accumulation Phase: Making Your Corpus Last
deaccumulation_strategy.body:
Building your nest egg is only half the battle. The real challenge is making it last. Here‚Äôs how you can create a steady income stream after you retire.

Systematic Withdrawal Plan (SWP)

An SWP allows you to withdraw a fixed amount from your mutual fund investments every month, just like a pension. This is a tax-efficient method because the rest of your corpus remains invested and continues to grow, helping you beat inflation.

Example: With a corpus of ‚Çπ2 Crore and a 7% annual return, a monthly SWP of ‚Çπ1 lakh could last for over 30 years.

Annuity Plans

An annuity is an insurance product where you pay a lump sum to an insurance company, and they guarantee you a fixed income for life. While this offers immense security, the returns (annuity rates) are often lower than what you might get from an SWP.

tax_rules.title: Taxes & Special Rules in India
tax_rules.body:
• Long-Term Capital Gains (LTCG): When you withdraw from equity mutual funds, gains over ‚Çπ1 lakh in a financial year are taxed at 10%. Planning your withdrawals strategically can help you minimize this tax.
  • Pension Taxation: Your pension income, whether from an annuity or other sources, is generally added to your income and taxed as per your applicable slab rate.
  • Special Rule for Returning NRIs (Section 89A): If you are an NRI returning to India, this rule allows you to defer paying tax on your foreign retirement accounts until you actually withdraw the money. This is a significant relief that helps avoid double taxation.

next_steps.title: Your Next Steps to a Secure Retirement
next_steps.cta1_desc: Use our PPF, NPS, and other calculators to model returns on specific investment vehicles.
next_steps.cta2_desc: Explore our full suite of calculators to plan for all your financial goals.

conclusion.title: Conclusion: Your Path to a Secure Retirement
conclusion.body: Retirement planning isn't just about hitting a number; it's about building a sustainable financial future you can count on. By using this comprehensive calculator and understanding the key variables that drive your corpus, you can create a realistic and actionable plan. Remember, the key is to start early, invest consistently, and review your plan annually. That's the surest way to a comfortable and stress-free retirement.

disclaimer.title: Disclaimer
disclaimer.body: The figures generated are hypothetical and for illustrative purposes only. The accuracy of the output depends on your inputs. Please consult a qualified financial professional for personalized advice.

retirement_corpus_calculator.faq_title: Frequently Asked Questions about Retirement Planning
retirement_corpus_calculator.faq_content:
What is a retirement corpus?

A retirement corpus is the total sum of money and assets an individual accumulates to support their financial needs during their non-working years. It's your financial nest egg for retirement.

How much corpus do I need to retire at 60?

This is highly personal, but a common rule is the 25x/30x rule: your corpus should be 25 to 30 times your current annual expenses. Use our calculator for a precise figure based on your lifestyle.

How do you calculate retirement corpus?

The core calculation uses the present value formula, factoring in your future annual expenses, inflation, life expectancy, and expected returns on investment. Our calculator does this complex math for you.

What inflation rate should I assume for retirement planning?

We use 6% by default as a long-term average for India, but this is a critical assumption. For a more conservative plan, consider a higher rate, especially for healthcare costs.

How much should a 30-year-old save per month for retirement?

This depends entirely on their desired retirement lifestyle. A 30-year-old aiming for a corpus of ‚Çπ2 crore by age 60 might need to save ‚Çπ15,000 - ‚Çπ20,000 per month via SIPs, assuming a 12% return.

Can I include EPF/PPF/NPS in the retirement corpus?

Absolutely. Your existing savings in EPF, PPF, NPS, mutual funds, and other assets should all be included in the 'Current Savings' input of the calculator.

faqs.question: What is retirement corpus?
faqs.answer: A retirement corpus is the total sum of money and assets an individual accumulates to support their financial needs during their non-working years. It's your financial nest egg for retirement.

faqs.question: How much corpus do I need to retire at 60?
faqs.answer: This is highly personal, but a common rule is the 25x/30x rule: your corpus should be 25 to 30 times your current annual expenses. Use our calculator for a precise figure based on your lifestyle.

faqs.question: How do you calculate retirement corpus?
faqs.answer: The core calculation uses the present value formula, factoring in your future annual expenses, inflation, life expectancy, and expected returns on investment. Our calculator does this complex math for you.

faqs.question: What inflation rate should I assume for retirement planning?
faqs.answer: We use 6% by default as a long-term average for India, but this is a critical assumption. For a more conservative plan, consider a higher rate, especially for healthcare costs.

faqs.question: How much should a 30-year-old save per month for retirement?
faqs.answer: This depends entirely on their desired retirement lifestyle. A 30-year-old aiming for a corpus of ‚Çπ2 crore by age 60 might need to save ‚Çπ15,000 - ‚Çπ20,000 per month via SIPs, assuming a 12% return.

faqs.question: Can I include EPF/PPF/NPS in the retirement corpus?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Your existing savings in EPF, PPF, NPS, mutual funds, and other assets should all be included in the 'Current Savings' input of the calculator.

methodology.title: Methodology & Update Log
methodology.body: This calculator uses standard financial formulas for future value (FV) and present value (PV) of annuities to project your retirement corpus and required SIP. All figures are illustrative. Last content update: September 2025. Financial formulas verified against established industry standards.

author_card.bio: Mahesh Chaube, CFP is a Certified Financial Planner with extensive experience helping Indian families build tax-efficient retirement and education plans. Mahesh specialises in retirement strategy, tax-optimised fixed-income planning and practical financial tools (calculators, worksheets) that simplify decision-making for everyday investors. He regularly advises fintechs and writes data-driven personal finance guides.
author_card.review_text: Reviewed & Verified by Experts: Laveena Vijayi ‚Äî BharatSaver Editorial Team. Data verified against PFRDA, CBDT, and Income Tax Department official calculators.
